name: Desktop Environment Ecosystem and Software Toolkit
description: A comprehensive set of features and packages covering desktop environments, critical path packages, application suites, multimedia support, software development toolkits, and additional plugins. This feature encompasses the software ecosystems specific to GNOME, KDE, LXDE, LXQt, and Xfce, making it easier to customize, enhance, and develop software for Linux desktop environments.
children: Extra plugins for the Xfce panel

name: System Utilities and Tools
description: A comprehensive collection of software utilities and tools to manage, administer, monitor, develop, debug, and enhance the functionality of Linux systems. This category encompasses features for system administration, hardware support, performance monitoring, development tools, network management, databases, security utilities, and scientific computation, catering to a wide range of use cases from personal desktop applications to enterprise-level server management.

name: Comprehensive Development and Productivity Suite
description: A comprehensive collection of tools, libraries, and frameworks for software development, educational purposes, technical writing, compatibility support, and multimedia production. This parent feature combines a wide range of functionalities catering to developers, educators, writers, musicians, and system administrators. It covers programming languages, platform compatibility, development environments, cross-compilation, scientific computing, and niche utilities, ensuring a robust ecosystem for a variety of use cases.

name: Server and Infrastructure Management
description: A comprehensive suite of features enabling the system to function as a robust server and manage infrastructure-related services. This parent feature encompasses functionality for diverse use cases such as 3D printing software, backup management, cloud infrastructure, network protocols, identity management, file storage, resilient clustering, high availability, web hosting, and email systems. It also integrates support for modern as well as legacy communication protocols and platforms, ensuring flexibility and scalability for complex deployments. The system can act as a central management hub with capabilities for authentication, directory services, load balancing, print services, and much more, catering to both enterprise and individual needs.

name: Linux Feature Ecosystem
description: The Linux Feature Ecosystem serves as a comprehensive parent feature that encompasses a wide array of sub-features integral to various use cases, installation types, and core functionalities of the Linux operating system. This parent feature unifies support for deployment targets (Atomic Host, Workstation, Server, ComputeNode, and Client), installation profiles (Base, Core, and Standard), critical path packages, conflict resolution across repositories and installation variants, and specialized user environments such as design suites and development libraries. It also provides tools for package building, Fedora packaging, and robust ostree support for streamlined deployments and updates. This feature set ensures Linux is versatile, modular, and adaptable to diverse operating environments and user needs.

name: Desktop Environments and Related Features
description: A comprehensive collection of graphical desktop environments, window managers, office suites, accessibility tools, and related applications tailored for a wide array of user needs, ranging from lightweight setups for low-spec hardware to full-featured environments for productivity, gaming, and media tasks. This parent feature encapsulates a diverse ecosystem of packages and tools designed to enhance users' interaction with the X Window System, Wayland, and other modern desktop protocols. It includes graphical user interfaces, essential software development tools, and additional utilities to provide a complete and versatile desktop experience for various platforms and user preferences.
children: Extra games for the GNOME Desktop

name: Cloud and Virtualization Management Tools
description: This parent feature encompasses a wide range of tools and software packages designed for managing cloud environments, virtualized systems, and containerized applications. It includes functionalities for bootloading, server management, virtualization hypervisors, guest and desktop agents, remote management, and platform-specific virtualization solutions. These tools enable seamless interaction with cloud infrastructure, efficient container orchestration, hypervisor management, and support for diverse virtualization platforms such as KVM, VMware, and Hyper-V. The feature also incorporates graphical and headless virtualization environments, remote desktop clients, and utilities for offline or online virtual image handling. Additionally, it addresses tools for managing virtual switches, Linux-based remote management, and infrastructure provisioning using Vagrant with libvirt support.
